bioghist.p: Dorothy Burr Thompson (1900-2001) was a prominent archaeologist and authority on Hellenistic terra cotta figurines. She received two degrees from Bryn Mawr College: a bachelor's degree, the College's first in Greek and archaeology, in 1923, and a Ph.D. in 1931. She studied at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens and was the first woman appointed a Fellow of the Athenian Agora excavations. In 1936, she unearthed and identified, in the Agora, the garden of the Temple of Hepaistos. She taught at colleges and universities including Bryn Mawr, Princeton University and the University of Pennsylvania and published more than 50 scholarly papers and books.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Dorothy Burr Thompson. Materials include correspondence, articles and reviews, lecture notes, photographs, and postcards. The collection also includes a series of notebooks on archaeological artifacts and sites.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
